tit.cmt: 「ほうぎょ」という読み方を出しました。

sen.j: 崩御（ほうぎょ）は、天皇、皇帝、国王、太皇太后、皇太后、皇后、その他君主等の死を婉曲的に、かつ敬意を込めて指す語。
sen.e: Demise refers to death of emperors, odai, kings, grand empress dowagers, empress dowagers, empresses, monarchs, and others euphemistically and respectfully.
Hogyo refers to the death of emperors, czar, kings, grand empress dowagers, empress dowagers, empresses, and other monarchs euphemistically and respectfully.
sen.cmt: 「demise」を「Hogyo」にしました。「皇帝」はodaiは適切ではないと思いますので、czarとしました。
sen.e: Hogyo refers to the death of emperors, czar, kings, grand empress dowagers, empress dowagers, empresses, and other monarchs euphemistically and respectfully.

sen.j: 死因については特に問わない。
sen.e: It does not matter why they died.
It does not matter why they died.
It does not matter why they died.

sen.j: 元々は中国起源の語であり、『礼記』曲礼篇に「天子の死は崩と曰ひ、諸侯は薨と曰ひ、大夫は卒と曰ひ、士は不禄と曰ひ、庶人は死と曰ふ」とある。
sen.e: It is derived from a Chinese word; 'The death of emperors is called 崩, the death of lords is called 薨, the death of daibu (master) is called 卒, the death of warrior is called 不禄, and the death of ordinary people is called 死' in the Kyokurei volume of "Book of Rites".
sen.cmt: 崩、薨、卒、不禄は漢字のまま残しました。
sen.e: It is derived from a Chinese word and there is a sentence, 'The death of emperors is called 崩 (ho), the death of lords is called 薨 (ko), the death of daibu (master) is called 卒 (sotsu), the death of warrior is called 不禄 (furoku), and the death of ordinary people is called 死 (shi)' in the Kyokurei volume of "Book of Rites".
sen.cmt: 漢字だけですと、「崩」が「ほう」だということが分かりませんので読み方をつけました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: It is derived from a Chinese word and there is a sentence, 'The death of emperors is called 崩 (ho), the death of lords is called 薨 (ko), the death of daibu (master) is called 卒 (sotsu), the death of warrior is called 不禄 (furoku), and the death of ordinary people is called 死 (shi)' in the Kyokurei volume of "Book of Rites".

sen.j: 新聞記事等では海外の国王などの死去にも使うことがある。
sen.e: The word may be used for demise of kings of other countries in newspaper articles.
The word may be used for demise of kings of other countries in newspaper articles.
The word may be used for demise of kings of other countries in newspaper articles.

sen.j: またお隠れになるとも表現する。
sen.e: It may be represented as 'pass away'.
It may be represented as 'hide'.
sen.cmt: 「pass away」ですと一般人にも使われるため「お隠れになる」のニュアンスが出ませんので表現を変えました。
sen.e: It may be represented as 'hide'.

sen.j: この表現が日本の皇室について用いられる理由としては、日本神話において天皇は神の末裔であり、一般の人間とはかけ離れた存在という思想背景があったためと解釈する説がある。
sen.e: This expression is used for the Japanese imperial court because there is an idea that the emperors are descendents of gods in the Japanese mythology and are different from human beings.
This expression is used for the Japanese Imperial family because there is an idea that the emperors are descendents of gods in the Japanese mythology and are different from ordinary people.
sen.cmt: 皇室の訳を単語リストに揃えました。「一般の人間」の表現を変えました。
sen.e: This expression is used for the Japanese Imperial family because there is an idea that the emperors are descendents of gods in the Japanese mythology and are different from ordinary people.

sen.j: 天皇が太陽神の子孫であるという思想、すなわち「天皇の死去＝太陽が雲に隠れる」から来ているともされる。
sen.e: It is said that it is derived from an idea that the emperor is a descendent of Taiyoshin (the sun god), i.e., 'demise of the emperor means that the sun goes behind a cloud'.
Another theory says that it is derived from an idea that the emperor is a descendent of Taiyoshin (the sun god), i.e., 'demise of the emperor means that the sun hides behind a cloud'.
sen.cmt: 上記とは違うもう一つの説であることを明確にしました。「雲に隠れる」を上記の「お隠れになる」と同様に「hide」にしました。
sen.e: Another theory says that it is derived from an idea that the emperor is a descendent of Taiyoshin (the sun god), i.e., 'demise of the emperor means that the sun hides behind a cloud'.

sen.j: 「雲隠れ」についても、現在では単に姿をくらますという意味合いで用いられるが、もともとはこれに由来する語である。
sen.e: The word 'Kumogakure' (vanish behind the clouds) is used to mean disappearance, but it is originally derived from this.
The word 'Kumogakure' (hide behind the clouds) is now used to mean disappearance, but it is originally derived from this idea.
sen.cmt: Kumogakureは上記に揃えてhideにしました。最後の「this」だけでは分かりにくいので「idea」を補いました。
sen.e: The word 'Kumogakure' (hide behind the clouds) is now used to mean disappearance, but it is originally derived from this idea.

sen.j: 天皇に次ぐ者、例えば皇太子、皇太子妃、親王、内親王などの皇族や、位階が三位以上の者の死は、死死の表現（こうきょ）の語を用いる。
sen.e: Kokyo (死死) is used to express the death of people following the emperor, for example, imperial family members, such as crown prince, crown princess, imperial prince, and imperial princess, or people higher than Sanmi in the rank.
sen.cmt: 死死は漢字のままとしました。
sen.e: 薨去 (Kokyo) is used to express the death of people next to the emperor in rank, for example, imperial family members, such as crown prince, crown princess, imperial prince, and imperial princess and people higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) in the rank.
sen.cmt: 「死死の表現」の部分は「薨去」の誤記だと思われます。「三位」の説明を補いしました。「次ぐ者」の表現を変えました。
sen.e: 薨去 (Kokyo) is used to express the death of people next to the emperor in rank, for example, imperial family members, such as crown prince, crown princess, imperial prince, and imperial princess and people higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) in the rank.

sen.j: 天皇の崩御に際しては、国の行事として「大喪の礼」が行われる。
sen.e: When the emperor demised, the Rites of an Imperial Funeral are performed as national events.
At the emperor's demise, 'the Rites of an Imperial Funeral' is performed as national event.
sen.cmt: 表現と文法を修正しました。
sen.e: At the emperor's demise, 'the Rites of an Imperial Funeral' is performed as national event.

sen.j: 律令制下においては貴人の死を指して崩御の他、皇太子や大臣などの死を意味する薨御、親王や三位以上の死を意味する薨去、王や女王、四位・五位以上の死を意味する卒去などの尊敬語が用いられた。
sen.e: In addition to 崩御, honorific languages, such as 薨御 that means the death of crown princes and ministers, 薨去 that means the death of imperial princes and persons with Sanmi or higher, and 卒去 that means the death of kings and princesses, and people higher than shii (Forth Rank) or goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank were used to express the death of nobles under the ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: 崩御、薨御、薨去は漢字のままとしました。
sen.e: In addition to 崩御, honorific languages, such as 薨御 that means the death of crown princes and ministers, 薨去 that means the death of imperial princes and persons with Sanmi or higher, and 卒去 that means the death of kings and princesses, and people higher than shii (Forth Rank) or goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank were used to express the death of nobles under the ritsuryo system.

In addition to 崩御, honorific languages, such as 薨御 that means the death of crown princes and ministers, 薨去 that means the death of imperial princes and persons with Sanmi or higher, and 卒去 that means the death of kings and princesses, and people higher than shii (Forth Rank) or goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank were used to express the death of nobles under the ritsuryo system.

sen.j: その他、主な死の尊敬語としては逝去などがある。
sen.e: Another main honorific language of death is 逝去.
sen.cmt: 逝去は漢字のままとしました。
sen.e: Another main honorific language of death is 逝去.
Another main honorific language of death is 逝去.

sen.j: 天皇の崩御から追号が決められるまでの期間、崩御した天皇については大行天皇と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The demised emperor is called Taiko-Tenno in the period from his death to determination of a posthumous title.
The demised emperor is called Taiko-Tenno during the period from his death to the determination of his posthumous title.
